review.title: Combining Probabilistic, Causal, and Normative Reasoning in CP-logic
review.abstract: In recent years the search for a proper formal definition of actual causation -- i.e., the relation of cause-effect as it is instantiated in specific observations, rather than general causal relations -- has taken on impressive proportions. In part this is due to the insight that this concept plays a fundamental role in many different fields, such as legal theory, engineering, medicine, ethics, etc. Because of this diversity in applications, some researchers have shifted focus from a single idealized definition towards a more pragmatic, context-based account. For instance, recent work by Halpern and Hitchcock draws on empirical research regarding people's causal judgments, to suggest a graded and context-sensitive notion of causation. Although we sympathize with many of their observations, their restriction to a merely qualitative ordering runs into trouble for more complex examples. Therefore we aim to improve on their approach, by using the formal language of CP-logic (Causal Probabilistic logic), and the framework for defining actual causation that was developed by the current authors using it. First we rephrase their ideas into our quantitative, probabilistic setting, after which we modify it to accommodate a greater class of examples. Further, we introduce a formal distinction between statistical and normative considerations.

To make T deterministic according to the decisions made in b is to transform T into T b by replacing the heads of the laws applied in b with the disjuncts selected from these heads in b. Intervening in a theory T that makes variable C wrong, which is called do (¬ C), removes C from the head of every law in which it occurs, and yields T | do (¬ C). sections.heading: 2.2 Actual Causation in CP-logic
sections.text: In recent years, many proposals for defining actual causality have entered the scene, such as (Hall and Paul 2003; Hall 2004; Hall 2004; 2007; Halpern and Pearl 2005; Vennekens 2011; Beckers and Vennekens 2012). In (Beckers and Vennekens), we developed a general definition that includes several of them. However, the idea behind our general definition is that one should first modify theory T into a theory T * that takes into account the influence of actual history b, and then assess causality by applying the probabilistic extension of counterfactual dependence. The available operations for constructing T * are to make laws deterministically in accordance with the decisions made in b and to remove laws. A specific definition is achieved by specifying which laws fall under the first category - referred to as intrinsic laws and referred to as int - and those that fall under the second - referred to irrelevant laws and referred to as errone.1 We then construct T.

Following HH, Def. 7 tries to circumvent the use of this intervention by simply requiring ¬ C to hold. However, this solution is not always available, and if it is not, it counterintuitively delivers counterintuitive results. We illustrate what goes wrong by using the following theory: (A: 0.1) ←.C ← C.E ¬ A. Consider the story in which A first occurs, followed by C and E. Intuitively, C is a strong cause of E, even if one considers the typicality of C. The law with A in one's head is intrinsic, and thus T normal (b).

sections.heading: 6 The Importance of Probabilities
sections.text: Since the HH approach lacks the quantification of normality that probabilities offer, it discards all witnesses who are less normal than the real world. A direct consequence is that a typical event - P > 0.5 - is never a cause, which is quite radical. By using probabilities, this qualitative criterion is no longer necessary: less normal witnesses simply affect our judgment less. Furthermore, HH order causes only by looking at the best witnesses. We present an example that illustrates the benefit of both abandoning their criterion and aggregating the normality of witnesses to ordered causes without sacrificing the influence of normality.

sections.heading: 6.4 The final definition
sections.text: This brings us to our final extension of a definition of actual causality. Definition 8 (Extension of actual causality. Starting from an extended theory T and a branch b, leaving both C and E in their sheets. We define that C is an actual cause of E in (T, b) if and only if P (T) NN (¬ E | do (¬ C)) х PTNN (¬ C) > 0.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: Our final definition expands our original definition of the actual cause (Def. 1) to include the main points raised by HH: (1) it allows for normative considerations and (2) it is able to take into account the normality of the cause, which is important when considering interventions and explanatory power. In addition, it also improves the HH account in several respects: • CP logic is more meaningful than structural models, so it can be applied to more examples (Vennekens, Denecker and Bruynooghe 2010). • The separation of normative and statistical normality allows a more precise description of the area. • As we no longer refer to the real world in the second factor, we can apply strict standards. • It is able to treat all examples from the HH paper equally well as Def. 7. • It can also treat the previous examples appropriately, as opposed to Def. 7.
